name_origin.etymology: The name 'Dwida' (دويدة) is the diminutive form of the Arabic word 'Doud' (دود), which means 'worm'. Therefore, 'Dwida' literally translates to 'little worm'. This follows a very common cross-cultural naming convention for thin pasta shapes (compare to Italian 'Vermicelli', which also means 'little worms'). In Tunisian cuisine, the term specifically refers to very thin pasta or vermicelli. While the specific recipe provided uses broken spaghetti, the name is retained because it mimics the shape of the traditional vermicelli used in this dish.
name_origin.sources_notes: Standard Maghrebi culinary terminology. The morphological pattern (Fu'ayla) is a standard Arabic diminutive form (e.g., 'Doud' becomes 'Dwida').

alternative_names.name: Douida
alternative_names.notes: Common French colonial transliteration found in Tunisian cookbooks

alternative_names.name: Dwida Jariya
alternative_names.notes: Literally 'Runny Dwida' - distinguishing the soup version from the steamed version (Dwida Mfawra)

alternative_names.name: Fdaouech
alternative_names.notes: A synonym often used in Tunisia for vermicelli or angel hair pasta

similar_dishes.name: Vermicelli in Broth
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical etymology (verme = worm) and pasta shape
similar_dishes.key_difference: Italian versions usually use chicken broth/clear broth; Tunisian Dwida uses a spicy tomato concentrate (harissa) base

similar_dishes.name: Sopa de Fideos
similar_dishes.similarity: Short thin pasta cooked in a tomato-based broth
similar_dishes.key_difference: Spicing profile (Tunisian uses caraway, coriander, and harissa)

similar_dishes.name: Dwida Mfawra
similar_dishes.key_difference: Mfawra is steamed (like couscous) and often served sweet with nuts or savory with meat, rather than as a soup

similar_dishes.name: Chorba
similar_dishes.similarity: The spicy red soup base is nearly identical
similar_dishes.key_difference: Chorba typically uses frik (green wheat) or barley, whereas Dwida uses pasta
